questions.text: A patient who underwent renal transplantation 8 months ago presents with pain at the site of the transplanted kidney, fever, and malaise. The renal biopsy findings of the kidney allograft are shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette of acute pyelonephritis after 8 months of kidney transplantation and the image showing enlarged tubular epithelial cells, nuclear inclusions, and interstitial inflammation suggest nephropathy caused by polyomavirus.

Polyomavirus is a viral pathogen causing pyelonephritis in kidney allografts. Immunosuppression of the allograft recipient can lead to reactivation of latent infection by polyomavirus and the development of nephropathy. This form of pyelonephritis is referred to as polyomavirus nephropathy.

Histopathology shows infection of tubular epithelial cell nuclei, leading to nuclear enlargement and intranuclear inclusions visible by light microscopy. An inflammatory interstitial inflammatory response is present.

Electron microscopy shows the presence of intranuclear viral inclusions, as seen in the image below.

Image A shows big clusters of viral particles in the nucleus and image B shows degrading organelles:


The following image shows enlarged tubular epithelial cells with nuclear inclusions (arrows):


Treatment: Reduction of immunosuppression.

Common opportunistic infections in kidney transplant recipients:

Early (1-6 months) :

  • Pneumocystis carinii (Option C)
  • Cytomegalovirus (Option A)
  • Legionella
  • Listeria (Option D)
  • Hepatitis B 
  • Hepatitis C

Late ( >6 months) : 

  • Aspergillus
  • Nocardia
  • BK virus (polyoma)
  • Herpes zoster
  • Hepatitis B
  • Hepatitis C

questions.text:
The CDC recommends all of the following vaccines for adults undergoing splenectomy except:

CDC- Centers for disease control and prevention
questions.solution:
Immunization and antibiotics have been recommended for preventing opportunistic infections following splenectomy. Japanese encephalitis vaccine is not recommended by CDC in post-splenectomy patients.

The CDC recommends the following vaccines for adults with asplenia.

Vaccine Recommendation
Tetanus (Td/Tdap) One dose every 10 years
Human papillomavirus Three doses for women ≤26 years of age or men ≤21 years of age (0, 2, 6 months)
Measles, mumps, rubella One or two doses  
Varicella Two doses (0, 4-8 weeks)  
Zoster One dose  
Influenza One dose annually  
Pneumococcal polysaccharide One or two doses  
Hepatitis A Two doses (0, 6-12 months or 0, 6-18 months)
Hepatitis B Two or Three doses (0, 1-2 months, 4-6 months)
Meningococcal One dose

Antibiotics: In children, prophylaxis with penicillin for at least 2 years after splenectomy is usually given.OPSI ( Overwhelming post-splenectomy Infection) is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. Most common within the first 2-3 years following splenectomy.

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery. In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

Related Pearl: Post-Splenectomy Care

Vaccination:

  • Patients should be vaccinated at least 2 weeks prior, and ideally 10 to 12 weeks prior to elective splenectomy. 
  • When vaccines cannot be given prior to emergency splenectomy, vaccines should be given at least two weeks after splenectomy.

Following vaccines are given:

  • Pneumococcal vaccine: 
    • A dose of PCV13 followed by PPSV23 ≥8 weeks later is advised. 
    • Revaccinate every five to seven years thereafter.
  • H. influenzae type b vaccine:
    • A single dose of Hib vaccine is recommended. 
    • Revaccination is needed every ten years.
  • Meningococcal vaccination:
    • Two doses of the MenACWY vaccine are given ≥8 weeks apart.
    • Revaccination is needed every five years.
  • Influenza vaccination:
    • Vaccination against seasonal influenza should be given annually.

Antibiotics: 

Daily prophylaxis: 

  • Penicillin and amoxicillin are preferred agents
    • For at least 1 year after surgery (at least up to the age of 5 yrs in children)
    • For immunocompromised, at least up to the age of 18 yrs

Early empirical:

  • Early empirical treatment to be initiated in presence of systemic symptoms of infection e.g - chills, rigor, fever, vomiting, etc.
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanic acid is the preferred choice for most adults and children
  • If allergic to beta-lactam, use levofloxacin/moxifloxacin.

Antithrombotics:

  • Low dose heparin for at least 4 weeks helps in perioperative thromboembolism prevention
  • In presence of extreme reactive thrombocytosis (>10,00,000/mm3) low dose aspirin can also be given.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: A patient with HIV had a CD4+ count of 170/ μL. Prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii is started. When can the prophylaxis be stopped?
questions.solution:
Prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii with trimethoprim-sulphamethoxazole can be stopped when CD4+ T-cell count >200/μL for ≥3 months.

Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is an opportunistic infection in immunocompromised patients. It usually occurs when the CD4 count falls below 200 cells/μL.

Patients usually present with fever and nonproductive cough with progressive shortness of breath. It can also affect other organs like lymph nodes, spleen, and liver.

The classic radiographic appearance of symptomatic pneumocystis pneumonia consists of diffuse bilateral symmetric interstitial infiltrates that are perihilar. CT will show diffuse ground-glass opacities.

Histopathology of the tissue will show foamy alveolar infiltrate and mononuclear interstitial infiltrates, which is pathognomonic of PCP. Specific stains like methenamine silver, toluidine blue O, or Giemsa can show the cysts. Other tests which are used for the diagnosis of PCP are polymerase chain reaction, (1→3)-β-d-glucan, etc.

The treatment and prevention of PCP are with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

Prophylaxis is indicated for other opportunistic infections like 

  • Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection, if CD4 counts fall below 50 cells/µL
  • Coccidioides, if CD count is <250/µL
  • Cryptococcus, when the CD count is <100/µL.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with HIV was started on ART. His CD4+ T-cell count at presentation was 38 cells/μL. Four weeks after treatment initiation, he developed a high-grade fever and cough with expectoration. His CD4+ count was 320 cells/μL and chest radiography showed mediastinal lymphadenopathy and consolidation. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In a patient who was recently diagnosed with HIV and started on ART, the appearance of symptoms like high-grade fever, cough with expectoration and pulmonary infiltrates on CXR after treatment initiation point to a diagnosis of immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). 

Following the initiation of effective anti-retroviral therapy, a paradoxical worsening of preexisting or untreated opportunistic infections may be seen in people living with HIV (PLHIV). This is known as immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS). IRIS is seen in up to 30% of the patients who are started on ART, and is particularly common in patients with untreated mycobacterial or fungal infections, or with CD4+ T-cell counts <50 cells/μL. Other risk factors for the development of IRIS include:

  • Rapid initial fall in HIV viral load due to ART
  • Severity of TB disease
  • Male sex and younger age

The underlying pathogenesis appears to be similar to a type IV hypersensitivity reaction and reflects the immediate improvements in immune function as there is a drop in the levels of HIV RNA. IRIS related to a known pre-existing infection is called paradoxical IRIS; IRIS associated with a previously undiagnosed condition is referred to as unmasking IRIS. Signs and symptoms can appear within two weeks to two years of starting ART and can include lymphadenitis, prolonged fever, pulmonary infiltrates, hepatitis and increase intracranial pressure.

IRIS is generally self-limiting and interruption of ART is rarely indicated. In most cases, recognition and management of ongoing infection with antimicrobial therapy is sufficient. Short-term therapy with corticosteroids or NSAIDs can be given to reduce the inflammation. Temporary cessation of ART is to be considered for potentially life-threatening forms of IRIS. For the prevention of IRIS in a patient with HIV and TB co-infection, anti-tubercular treatment is started first and then ART is added two weeks later. 

Related Pearl: Opportunistic Infections/HIV related conditions and ART initiation

Clinical scenario Action 
Any undiagnosed active infection with fever Diagnose and treat first; start Anti-Retroviral Therapy (ART) when stable
Tuberculosis (TB) Start TB treatment first; start ART as soon as possible after 2 weeks and before 2 months. For those with CD4 less than 50/cmm, start ART within 2 weeks Caution is needed for PLHIV with TB meningitis, since immediate ART is associated with more severe adverse events than initiating ART 2 months after the start of TB treatment

Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP)

 Treat PCP first; start ART when PCP treatment is completed
Invasive fungal diseases: Oesophageal candidiasis, penicilliosis, histoplasmosis Start treatment for oesophageal candidiasis first; start ART as soon as the patient can swallow comfortably. Treat penicilliosis, and histoplasmosis first; start ART when the patient is stabilized or opportunistic infection treatment is completed.
Cryptococcal meningitis Treat cryptococcal meningitis. ART initiation should be deferred until there is evidence of sustained clinical response to anti-fungal therapy and after 4 weeks of induction and consolidation treatment with amphotericin B containing regimen.
Bacterial pneumonia Treat pneumonia first; start ART when treatment is completed
Malaria Treat malaria first; start ART when treatment is completed
Acute diarrhoea which may reduce absorption of ART Diagnose the cause and treat diarrhoea first; start ART when diarrhoea is stabilized or controlled
Non-severe anaemia (Hb< 9 g/dl) Start ART if no other causes for anaemia are found (HIV is often the cause of anaemia) 
Skin conditions such as PPE and seborrhoeic dermatitis, psoriasis, HIV-related exfoliative dermatitis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems) 
Suspected Mycobacterium Avium Complex (MAC), Cryptosporidiosis and Microsporidiosis Start ART (ART may resolve these problems)
Cytomegalovirus retinitis Start treatment for CMV urgently and start ART after 2 weeks of CMV treatment 
Toxoplasmosis Treat toxoplasmosis; start ART after 6 weeks of treatment and when the patient is stabilized

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease underwent renal transplantation. 2 months later he returned with severe hemodynamic compromise and hemoglobin decline. Delayed anastomotic bleeding is suspected. Which of the following pathogens is most commonly associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
For the given clinical scenario, among the provided alternatives, the pathogen that is commonly associated is donor-derived Candida albicans. The likely cause of delayed anastomotic bleeding is the development of a mycotic aneurysm associated with Candida infection. 

Delayed anastomotic hemorrhage may also manifest a few weeks or months later due to the formation of a mycotic aneurysm. The most frequently encountered causal organism is Candida albicans which is acquired from the donor. The prompt surgical intervention of a ruptured mycotic aneurysm necessitates an expeditious graft nephrectomy procedure.

The post-renal transplant can be complicated by the formation of a hematoma that has the potential to form within the transplant bed during the initial days following the surgical procedure. This phenomenon frequently occurs as a result of haemorrhaging from minute disconnected blood vessels in the renal hilum that were not discernible during the surgical procedure. In the present scenario, the patient exhibits hemodynamic stability, hence allowing for the utilization of CT angiography as a means of investigation. Following this, a subsequent re-exploration procedure can be conducted to facilitate the removal of the hematoma.

Anastomotic haemorrhage, albeit infrequent, may also manifest as a potential complication. The observed condition manifests as haemorrhagic shock, characterized by a decrease in haemoglobin levels to less than 50 g/L. The current scenario poses a significant risk to the patient's life, necessitating an urgent return to the operating theatre. Repairing a defect in an arterial or venous anastomosis may be a potential course of action, although it is frequently necessary to resort to transplant nephrectomy.

Other options 

Option A: Cytomegalovirus is a common cause of graft dysfunction and not anastomotic haemorrhage in solid organ transplants between 1-6 months post-transplant.

Option B: Nocardia is a common cause of graft dysfunction and not anastomotic haemorrhage in solid organ transplants more than 6 months post-transplant.

Option C: BK virus is emerging as an important cause of graft dysfunction after renal transplantation. Infection with the BK virus is almost universal during childhood, with latent infection in the epithelium of the urinary tract. Immunosuppression causes lytic BK virus replication with graft involvement in 1–5% of renal transplants. Infection with the polyomavirus BK has been found in association with progressive nephropathy and ureteral obstruction more commonly 6 months post-transplant. Detection of BK viral DNA in blood and urine has been useful for diagnosis and monitoring response to therapy. BK virus-associated nephropathy is controlled by cidofovir, IV immunoglobulin. The only effective treatment is to reduce the level of immunosuppression. 

The most common Opportunistic Infections in Renal Transplant Recipients: 

Peritransplant

(less than 1 month)

 Early (1-6 months) Late (more than 6 months)
Wound infection Pneumocystis jiroveci Aspergillus
Herpes virus Cytomegalovirus Nocardia
Oral candidiasis Hepatitis B BK Virus (polyoma)
Urinary tract infection Listeria Herpes Zoster

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with HIV presented with weakness affecting the left upper and lower limbs. On examination he was confused and had a temperature of 100.4°F. He had recently been treated for a Pneumocystis carinii infection. The CD4 count was 150/μl. CT scan of the brain with contrast revealed subcortical atrophy and multiple contrast-enhancing ring lesions in the cortex and subcortical areas. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis.

The CT scan is consistent with the diagnosis; the subcortical atrophy probably represents HIV encephalopathy. The exact cause of CNS involvement in HIV infection is largely influenced by the CD4 count.

  • Patients with CD4 counts >500/μl have benign and malignant brain tumours similar to those seen in immunocompetent patients.
  • Patients with a CD4 count of between 200/μl and 500/μl often have cognitive disorders associated with HIV such as HIV dementia and progressive leukoencephalopathy, which are not mass lesions.
  • Patients with a CD4 count <200/μl have either opportunistic CNS infections or HIV-related cerebral tumours.

Opportunistic infections include toxoplasmosis, TB, CMV and cryptococcal meningitis.

Toxoplasmosis is by far the most common cerebral mass lesion seen in HIV patients and is usually associated with multiple ring-enhancing lesions either in the cortico-medullary junction or around the basal ganglia.

Patients often have headaches, confusion and fever. Focal neurological signs or seizures are common. The other opportunistic infections rarely result in mass lesions in the absence of disseminated infection.

The image given below shows ring-enhancing lesions seen in cerebral toxoplasmosis.

Primary CNS lymphoma does display some degree of contrast enhancement but it is usually nodular or patchy; however, lesions may be multiple and difficult to differentiate from toxoplasmosis. Thallium single photon emission computed tomography is useful in differentiating cerebral toxoplasmosis from cerebral lymphoma. Primary CNS lymphoma is rarer than cerebral toxoplasmosis in HIV infection. Generally, patients with multiple ring-enhancing lesions on the CT scan with mass effect are treated empirically for toxoplasma infection for two weeks with a combination of pyrimethamine and sulphadiazine. Failure of a radiological response (on CT scan) is an indication for brain biopsy to enable an alternative diagnosis such as lymphoma.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male student presented with diarrhea and acute onset cough with thick sticky sputum. There is a history of repeated lung infections since childhood. Chest Xray shows evidence of bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis. A gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria  is isolated which exhibits the following color change on Mueller-Hinton agar. All of the following conditions are caused by this bacteria except?
questions.solution:
The image shows the production of blue-green-colored pyocyanin, a pigment produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa which causes lung infection in the case of cystic fibrosis patients. Glanders disease is caused by Burkholderia Mallei, not pseudomonas.

Cystic fibrosis (CF) is an autosomal recessive exocrinopathy affecting multiple epithelial tissues. The gene product responsible for CF is the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) which produces defective (CFTR) protein in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, and pancreas.  

In the lungs, abnormal CFTR leads to thick, sticky mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance. The patient will have recurrent respiratory infections with the development of bronchiectasis. Patients with cystic fibrosis also have fat malabsorption secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, hence the increased stool fat.

A complex bacterial flora that includes Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Pseudomonas aeruginosa is routinely cultured from CF sputum. Infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa is common in adults with CF and it exhibits a stereotypic mode of pathogenesis; a sentinel and early colonization event that poses risk of lifelong pulmonary infection by the same genetic strain.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria. Pyocyanin is a bluish-green pigment, produced only by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and not produced by any other Pseudomonas species. Pigments produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa and many other species include Pyoverdin (Greenish-yellow), Pyorubin (Red), Pyomelanin (Brown). Production of a combination of pyocyanin and pyoverdin can be visualised as a blue green color on Mueller Hinton agar plate.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Opportunistic infections and hospital acquired infections
  • Shanghai fever: It manifests as severe enteric disease and sepsis with invasive disease in previously healthy infants.
  • Malignant otitis externa in diabetics
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis) is a common type of folliculitis, which causes inflammation of hair follicles.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum - Hemorrhagic necrosis of skin occurs often in sepsis caused by P. aeruginosa. It usually occurs in patients who are critically ill and immunocompromised. The characteristic lesions of ecthyma gangrenosum are hemorrhagic pustules that evolve into a necrotic (black) ulcer.
  • Green-nail syndrome: It results from frequent submersion of the hands in water. Infection with Pseudomonas causes diffusion of pyocyanin into the nail bed.

Glander's disease is caused by Burkholderia mallei. It is a disease primarily of equine animals (horses and mules) but, capable of being transmitted to other animals and to human beings (among grooms and veterinarians).

Image: Ecthyma gangrenosum. Note the black central eschar surrounded by an erythematous edematous halo.

questions.text:
Which of the following vaccines are indicated in elderly patients with no other risk factors?
  1. Influenza
  2. Haemophilus influenzae
  3. Recombinant zoster
  4. Pneumococcal
  5. Meningococcal
questions.solution:
In otherwise healthy elderly patients, the recommended vaccines are:

  • Inactivated or recombinant influenza vaccine, 1 dose annually
  • Td or Tdap booster, every 10 years
  • Zoster recombinant vaccine
  • Pneumococcal vaccine
  • COVID-19 vaccine

The zoster recombinant vaccine is not indicated for the prevention of varicella. This vaccine is given to prevent episodes of herpes zoster and post-herpetic neuralgia. It is indicated regardless of a previous episode of zoster.

All adults ≥65 years of age should also receive pneumococcal vaccination. This is in the form of pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV) first, followed by pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccine (PPSV23) after an interval.

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with the findings below. He was born at 38 weeks of gestation to a mother who was retropositive. Which other condition can this child develop in the clinical stage that he is currently in?
questions.solution:
This child with oesophageal candidiasis and Kaposi's sarcoma as shown in the images respectively is most likely suffering from AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) clinical stage 4. The other feature seen in this stage is CMV (cytomegalovirus) retinitis. This is according to the WHO (World Health Organization) staging of AIDS in children with confirmed HIV infection.

CMV retinitis is a common opportunistic ocular infection seen in patients who are retro-positive. Ocular symptoms of CMV infection include reduced vision, floaters, and anterior uveitis. In the later stages, the patient can develop cataracts. Retinitis usually starts in the periphery with flame-shaped retinal hemorrhages. The direct spread of the infection can lead to optic neuritis. It can result in visual loss if left untreated.

The pizza appearance seen in CMV retinitis is shown below:


Other Options:

Option A: Persistent parotid enlargement is seen in Stage 2

Option B: Persistent oral candidiasis is seen in Stage 3

Option D: Persistent hepatosplenomegaly is seen in Stage 2

Related Pearl: Clinical stages of HIV in children/ infants

Stage 1

  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy

Stage 2

General-

  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly
  • Recurrent or chronic upper respiratory infections (otitis media, otorrhoea, sinusitis, tonsilitis)
  • Fungal nail infections

Oral-

  • Recurrent oral ulcerations
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement
  • Linear gingival erythema

Skin- 

  • Papular pruritic eruptions
  • Extensive wart virus infection
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum
  • Herpes zoster

Stage 3

General-

  • Unexplained moderate malnutrition not adequately responding to standard therapy
  • Unexplained persistent diarrhea (14 days or more)
  • Unexplained persistent fever (above 37.6 °C intermittent or constant, for longer than one month)
  • Unexplained anemia (<8 g/dL), neutropenia (<0.5 x 109/L) or chronic thrombocytopenia (<50 × 109/L)

Oral-

  • Persistent oral candidiasis (after first 6-8 weeks of life)
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia
  • Acute necrotizing ulcerative gingivitis/periodontitis

Respiratory-

  • Pulmonary TB/ Lymph node TB
  • Severe recurrent bacterial pneumonia
  • Symptomatic lymphoid interstitial pneumonitis
  • Chronic HIV-associated lung disease including bronchiectasis

Stage 4

General-

  • Unexplained severe wasting, stunting or malnutrition not responding to standard therapy
  • Chronic herpes simplex infection; (oro-labial or cutaneous of more than one month's duration or visceral at any site)
  • Extrapulmonary TB and disseminated non-tuberculosis mycobacterial infection
  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Oesophageal candidiasis (or candidiasis of trachea, bronchi or lungs)
  • Cytomegalovirus infection; retinitis or CMV infection affecting another organ, with onset at age over 1 month)
  • Disseminated endemic mycosis (extrapulmonary histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Chronic cryptosporidiosis and isosporiasis
  • Symptomatic HIV-associated nephropathy or HIV-associated cardiomyopathy

Neurological-

  • Central nervous system toxoplasmosis (after one month of life)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • Cerebral or B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis (including meningitis)

Respiratory-

  • Pneumocystis pneumonia
  • Recurrent severe bacterial infections (e.g., empyema, pyomyositis, bone or joint infection, meningitis, but excluding pneumonia)

questions.text:
Which of the following are AIDS-defining illnesses?
  1. Primary brain lymphoma
  2. Toxoplasmosis of brain
  3. Oral candidiasis
  4. Wasting syndrome
  5. Invasive aspergillosis
questions.solution:
Out of the given conditions, primary brain lymphoma, toxoplasmosis of the brain, and wasting syndrome are considered AIDS-defining illnesses. 

While candidiasis of the respiratory tract (trachea, bronchi, and lungs) and esophagus is considered to be an AIDS-defining illness, oral candidiasis (oral thrush) is not AIDS-defining. Similarly, invasive aspergillosis is not seen in patients with AIDS unless there is concomitant neutropenia or glucocorticoid administration.

Generalized wasting is also an AIDS-defining condition. It is defined as involuntary weight loss of >10% body weight with fever and chronic diarrhea lasting >30 days without any other cause. Severe muscle wasting with myofiber degeneration is seen in this condition. The most severe form of neurocognitive disorder associated with HIV, HIV-associated dementia, is also considered to be an AIDS-defining condition.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with persistent diarrhea. Microscopic examination of the stool reveals oocysts containing 2 sporocysts, each having two sporozoites, as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism.
questions.solution:
Diarrhea in an HIV patient is suggestive of a coccidian (one-celled) parasitic infestation. Kinyoun stain–positive oocysts that are round, with 2 sporocysts, and each sporocyst having two sporozoites, as seen in the given image, are findings suggestive of Cyclospora.

Points in favor:

  • HIV patient with diarrhea
  • Oocysts are round, size of 8–12 μm, containing 2 sporocysts, each having two sporozoites which are variably acid-fast on staining.

The image given below shows the presence of four modified acid-fast stain-positive Cyclospora cayetanensis oocysts in the field of view. Note that the staining is variable among the four oocysts.

Treatment of Cyclospora infection includes fluid replacement and cotrimoxazole.

Other options:

Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

Acid-fast detection  Uniformly acid-fast Variable acid-fast Uniformly acid-fast
Sporulation of the oocyst Occurs inside the host cell Occurs in soil Occurs in soil
Diagnostic form Sporulated cyst Unsporulated cyst Unsporulated oocyst


The image given below demonstrates uniformly acid-fast oocysts of Cryptosporidium parvum.


The image given below shows the uniformly acid-fast, large, oval oocysts of Isospora belli.


Microspora spp. are unicellular, obligate intracellular parasites causing opportunistic illnesses, such as protracted diarrhea, in immunocompromised patients. They produce spores (not oocyst), which are the infective stage of microsporidia. Spores are 2–4 μm in size and oval to cylindrical in shape, with a polar filament. Spores are gram-positive and acid-fast.

questions.text: A 61-year-old man presents with fever, productive cough with blood-streaked sputum, and chest pain for a week. He underwent a bone marrow transplant for leukemia 8 months ago and is on immunosuppressive therapy. Examination reveals crackles over the left lung.  Lab reports show a leukocyte count of 2500/mm3 and neutropenia. A CT scan of the chest is shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This given clinical vignette with a CT scan of the lung showing a pulmonary nodule with a "halo sign" is suggestive of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis caused by Aspergillus species—most commonly Aspergillus fumigatus. While features such as patchy consolidation(air bronchogram), opacities, and infiltrates are present in other conditions mentioned above, a halo sign is typical of infection due to Aspergillus species and hence it is the most likely cause of this patient's condition.

Radiological signs of aspergillosis include:  

  • Patchy consolidation: A common sign of invasive aspergillosis, this can progress even with broad-spectrum antibiotics.  
  • Nodules and lesions: Multiple nodules or peripheral, wedged-shaped lesions can appear as the disease progresses.  
  • Cavitation: These lesions can frequently become cavitated.  
  • Air-crescent sign: This sign can appear in 50% of cases, usually about two weeks after the onset of the disease.  
  • Halo sign: This sign represents pulmonary haemorrhage and coagulative necrosis.  
  • Pleural thickening: This can be the earliest radiographic sign, and may be reversible.  
  • Indolent mass: This can be seen on a radiograph, and may involve the upper lobes.   

Clinically, aspergillus infection may have various presentations-

  • Invasive pulmonary aspergillosis- invasive pulmonary aspergillosis is seen most commonly in immunocompromised patients. It is characterized by cough, pleuritic chest pain, and hemoptysis. 
  • Aspergilloma- They are mass-like fungus balls that are typically composed of Aspergillus fumigatus and are a non-invasive form of pulmonary aspergillosis. They occur in patients with normal immunity but structurally abnormal lungs, with pre-existing cavities. The most common underlying condition is pulmonary tuberculosis.
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA)- It is an eosinophilic pulmonary disorder caused by a hypersensitivity reaction to the colonization of airways by Aspergillus fumigatus. It occurs almost exclusively in patients with asthma or cystic fibrosis. In chronic cases, repeated episodes of bronchial obstruction, inflammation, and mucoid impaction lead to central bronchiectasis, fibrosis, and respiratory failure. Some patients can also develop chronic cavitary lesions. It is diagnosed serologically, based on the presence of:
    • Serum IgE > 1000 IU/ml
    • Positive skin prick test in response to A.fumigatus extract
    • Detection of Aspergillus-specific antibodies
    • Eosinophilia >500 cells/μL.

 Diagnosis is established using-

  • Serological assays- Serum fungal biomarkers such as galactomannan and 1,3 Beta D Glucan levels may be used. 1,3-β-d-glucan (BDG) is a cell wall polysaccharide found in candida, aspergillus, and pneumocystis jiroveci. 1,3 beta D Glucan assay is a chromogenic, quantitative enzyme immunoassay (EIA) designed to detect beta D Glucan by using purified, lysed Limulus polyphemus amebocytes. These cells contain components of the Limulus clotting cascade, including factors C and G, which initiate coagulation in the presence of bacterial liposaccharide and Beta D Glucan, respectively. By eliminating factor C from the lysate, activation of the cascade is limited to BDG alone and can therefore detect the presence of the same. 1,3 Beta D Glucan levels of ≥80 pg/mL are considered positive.
  • Imaging- Chest imaging such as CT scan reveals nodules with surrounding ground-glass opacities. This is called the "halo sign". It may also reveal cavitations with air-fluid levels. This is called the "air-crescent sign". 
  • Fungal staining and culture- Can be done from sputum samples, and bronchoalveolar lavage. They can be cultured on Sabouraud's agar at 25-37°C, the colonies have characteristic features- A.fumigatus shows dark green colonies, A.niger is black, and A .flavus is yellow-green.

Voriconazole is the drug of choice in the treatment of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis.  

The characteristic microscopic appearance of Aspergillus fumigatus is shown below:

  • Vesicle is conical.
  • Phialides are arranged in a single row.
  • Conidia arise from the upper third of the vesicle and are hyaline.

questions.text: A patient presents with an abscess at a vaccine injection site. Microbiological studies reveal the cause to be acid-fast bacteria, growing rapidly on Lowenstein Jensen medium in 3 days without producing any pigment. Which of the following is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette is an injection site abscess due to mycobacterial cause, most likely due to M. chelonae which commonly causes post-trauma infections, injection abscesses, and catheter-related infections. M. chelonae is a rapidly growing (within 7 days) non-tuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) that does not produce pigments.

M. fortuitum is also associated with injection site abscesses, and belongs to the same group as M. chelonae (Rapid growing, non pigment producing).

NTM are a diverse group of mycobacteria that are isolated from environmental sources and animals. They are opportunistic pathogens, occasionally causing human infection. No man-to-man transmission is reported.

NTM are classified based on the Runyon classification system into 4 groups.

Group Growth Pigment Examples Disease
I Slow Yellow orange on light (photochromogen)

M. kansasii

M. marinum

1. Similar to TB

2. Swimming pool graniuloma
II Slow Yellow orange on light and dark (scotochromogen) M. scrofulaceum Cervical adenitis
III Slow No pigment (Non-photochromogens) M. avium intracellulare complex(MAC) Similar to TB, opportunistic infection in AIDS
IV Rapid (Within 7 days) No pigment

M. fortuitum

M. chelonae

 Soft tissue, lung, bone, CNS, eye infections

Other options:

Option B: M. kansasii is a photochromogen that produces pigment when exposed to light, grows slowly and predominantly affects the lung.

Option C: M. scrofulaceum is a scotochromogen that produces pigment regardless of light exposure, shows slow growth and is responsible for lymph node infections.

Option D: M. ulcerans is a non-photochromogen that does not produce pigment, shows slow growth and is responsible for subcutaneous nodules and ulcers.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old male patient successfully underwent elective CABG 3 days before. He is now acutely confused with a temperature of 102°F, SpO2 of 92%, and has also developed purulent sputum. CBC shows leukocytosis. Chest X-ray shows a new right-sided infiltrate. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

CABG - Coronary artery bypass-graft

SpO2- Oxygen saturation

CBC - Complete blood count

CTPA -  CT pulmonary angiogram

choices.text: Perform lung biopsy and start antibiotics after culture results
Start treatment as per hospital's local antibiogram for nosocomial pneumonia
Perform CTPA to rule out pulmonary embolism
Administer antipyretics and observe the patient

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of nosocomial pneumonia and the next best step in managing this patient is to start antibiotics as per the hospital's local antibiogram for nosocomial pneumonia.

Pneumonia is a lung parenchymal infection that can be community-acquired or nosocomial. Nosocomial pneumonia can be hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).

Treatment should be started as soon as possible due to the high mortality rate. Empirical antibiotics are first given and narrowed to specific antibiotics after the finalized culture reports. The initial empirical treatment is based on each hospital's local antibiogram (profile of antimicrobial susceptibility). This is done to guide the optimal choice of antibiotics and reduce the risk of creating antibiotic resistance and exposing the sick patient to unnecessary drugs. 

HAP occurs > 48 hours after admission to the hospital. The diagnosis should be made after excluding the possibility of any infections present at the time of admission. VAP is diagnosed when clinical features and positive respiratory samples consistent with pneumonia develop >48 hours after endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Clinical diagnosis is made by clinical and radiological findings:

  • 2 or more clinical findings of:
    • fever
    • purulent sputum
    • worsening respiratory status
    • leukocytosis
  • 1 or more new/progressive lung opacities on chest imaging

The most common organisms responsible for HAP are Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Klebsiella pneumoniae. VAP is also associated with Acinetobacter species. VAP can be prevented by reducing the duration of intubation and preferring non-invasive ventilation methods.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman who was treated for COVID-19 one month back now presents with a black, foul-smelling discharge from the nose and suppuration of the left eye. Culture of discharge on Sabouraud agar would reveal colonies showing:

choices.text: Broad hyphae with acute angle branching
Septate hyphae with acute angle branching

questions.solution:
Microscopy showing broad aseptate hyphae with irregular branching is suggestive of Mucor.

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic infection caused principally by species of Rhizopus oryzae (most prevalent), mucor, and lichtheimia. It is seen in patients with diabetes mellitus, leukemias, lymphomas, long-term corticosteroid use, severe burns, and immunodeficiencies.

The common clinical form is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis in which there is an invasion of the blood vessels in the nasal cavity, eyes, and brain causing thrombosis, infarction, and necrosis. The blackish discoloration is due to arterial and venous thrombosis leading to gangrene.

Diagnosis can be made by staining them with 10% potassium hydroxide and culture. On Sabouraud agar at 30-37°C, they appear as grey-white colonies with a thick cottony, fluffy surface. Under the microscope, they appear as irregularly branched broad hyphae with aerial sporangiophores which end in a sporangium (a sac containing spores). 

Intravenous administration of amphotericin B is the treatment of choice for invasive mucormycosis. Surgical debridement and control of underlying predisposing causes should also be done.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby with recurrent infections was brought with complaints of diaper rash. On examination, it is found that he has no tonsils. A swab of the rash shows candidal growth. What is the likely etiology ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with absent tonsils(B cell dysfunction) and recurrent diaper rash positive for candida(T cell dysfunction) is suggestive of severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID). SCID is a defect in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Usually, the defect lies in the T-cell compartment with secondary impairment in humoral immunity.

Affected infants present with prominent thrush (oral candidiasis), extensive diaper rash, and failure to thrive. Some patients develop a morbilliform rash shortly after birth because maternal T cells are transferred across the placenta and attack the fetus, causing graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).

Persons with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including: 

  • Candida albicans
  • Pneumocystis jiroveci
  • Pseudomonas
  • Cytomegalovirus
  • Varicella

There are 2 types of SCID based on inheritance:

1. X-linked SCID is the most common form and hence it is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect is the mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors. T-cell numbers are greatly reduced, and although B cells may be normal in number, antibody synthesis is impaired because of the lack of T-cell help. The thymus contains lobules of undifferentiated epithelial cells resembling fetal thymus.

2. Autosomal recessive is most commonly caused due to deficiency of the enzyme adenosine deaminase (ADA). The deficiency of ADA leads to the accumulation of deoxyadenosine and its derivatives (e.g., deoxy-ATP). They are toxic to rapidly dividing immature lymphocytes, especially those of the T-cell lineage. Hence, there may be a greater reduction in the number of T lymphocytes.

In the two most common forms (γc mutation and ADA deficiency), the thymus is small and devoid of lymphoid cells. In SCID caused by ADA deficiency, remnants of Hassall’s corpuscles can be found.

Note: X-linked SCID is the first human disease in which gene therapy has been successful.

Other Options:
Option A Chronic granulomatous disease is due to a defect in phagocytes oxidase which is required for the generation of superoxide. Its defect results in recurrent infections with catalase-positive microbes.

Option B Transient hypogammaglobulinemia can be seen in children less than 6 months old and is characterized by a low IgG level. This condition resolves after 6 months after birth.

Option D Reduced immunoglobulin titres is the defect in Bruton's agammaglobulinemia. Patients usually have no infection till 6 months as they're protected by their mother's antibodies. 

Related Pearl: Primary immunodeficiency disorders

Affected component of the immune system

Disorder

Humoral immunity: Problems with B cells and their antibody production
  • Common variable immunodeficiency
  • Selective immunoglobulin deficiency, such as IgA deficiency
  • Transient hypogammaglobulinemia of infancy
  • X-linked agammaglobulinemia

Cellular immunity: Problems with T cells 
  • Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • DiGeorge syndrome
  • X-linked lymphoproliferative syndrome

Combined humoral and cellular immunity: Problems with B and T cells
  • Ataxia-telangiectasia
  • Hyperimmunoglobulinemia M syndrome
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome

Phagocytes: Problems with the movement or killing 
  • Chronic granulomatous disease
  • Chédiak-Higashi syndrome (rare)
  • Tuftsin deficiency
  • Cyclic neutropenia
  • Leukocyte adhesion defects

Complement proteins: 

Deficiency of complement proteins
  • Complement component 1 (C1) inhibitor deficiency (hereditary angioedema)
  • Terminal complement deficiency (C5-C9): Recurrent Neisseria infections

questions.text: An unimmunized 2-year-old child presented with coryza, conjunctivitis, and bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth. A day later, he developed a maculopapular rash on the face and neck. All of the following viruses belong to the same family as the causative agent, except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of infection with measles virus which belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae. All the given viruses belong to Paramyxoviridae except Molluscum contagiosum, which belongs to Poxviruses.

Paramyxoviridae is a family of single-stranded RNA viruses which include the measles virus, mumps virus, parainfluenza virus, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), Newcastle disease virus, Nipah virus, and Hendra virus.

The measles virus has an incubation period of 7-18 days, after which the prodrome phase begins with mild fever, conjunctivitis, upper respiratory tract infection, and pathognomic Koplik spots (Bluish-white spots in his buccal mucosa near the lower molar teeth). This is followed by the appearance of maculopapular rash after 4th day of fever, which begins at the face and spreads to the torso and extremities. Lymphadenopathy may be present.

The image below shows the characteristic rashes and the koplik spots seen in measles.

questions.text: A patient has recurrent bouts of infections and all the causative organisms show a positive reaction for the biochemical test shown below. Nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test shows yellow color. What is the most likely cause of infections in this case?
questions.solution:
The image given shows a slide with a positive catalase test. Recurrent infections with catalase-positive organisms with a negative (yellow) nitroblue tetrazolium dye reduction test is seen in chronic granulomatous disease.

Chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) is an inherited defect in microbiocidal activity. In this condition, there is a failure in the formation of reactive oxygen species due to defective phagocytes NADPH oxidase. This leads to the phagocytic inability to kill specific microbes.

Catalase is an enzyme that inactivates hydrogen peroxide. When these patients are infected with catalase-negative organisms, the patient's immune system can use hydrogen peroxide produced by the organism to create reactive oxygen species. However, in catalase-positive organisms, the hydrogen peroxide produced is rapidly destroyed by catalase, and therefore, the patient's immune response cannot use it to produce reactive oxygen species. Thus, most patients present with pneumonia due to catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus aureus, Burkholderia cepacia, Serratia marcescens, Nocardia, and Aspergillus species. 

The catalase test is demonstrated by placing a microbial colony in hydrogen peroxide (H2O2). The catalase enzyme degrades hydrogen peroxide to water and oxygen. The liberated O2 is seen as gas bubbles and is a positive test.

Patients have recurrent bacterial and fungal infections. The symptoms begin within the first two years of life, affecting the pulmonary, gastrointestinal, skin, and lymphatic drainage of these organs. Nitroblue tetrazolium is used as a diagnostic test. The yellow-colored Nitroblue tetrazolium dye is converted to a purple insoluble substance (positive) in the presence of oxidative burst by the free oxygen radicals so formed. A negative test (yellow color remains) is seen in CGD.

Other options:

Option A: Deficiency of terminal complement components (C5-C8) leads to recurrent infections with gram-negative cocci such as with Neisseria. 

Options B and C: Asplenia and Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome have increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms like pneumococci, meningococci, and Haemophilus influenzae.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of AIDS presents to the OPD with fever, chills, malaise and weight loss. On examination, angiomatous skin lesions are noted as given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture & image suggest the diagnosis as bacillary angiomatosis which is a vascular, proliferative form of Bartonella infection that occurs primarily in immunocompromised persons. It can be caused by either Bartonella henselae or Bartonella quintana.

It is the second-most-common cause of angiomatous skin lesions in persons infected with HIV. Cutaneous lesions due to bacillary angiomatosis may take one of the following forms:

  • Solitary or multiple red, purple, flesh-colored, or colorless papules (hemangioma-like lesions) varying in size from 1 mm to several centimeters.
  • Nodules, often covered with a fine, tightly adherent scale
  • Large polypoid exophytic masses

Visceral involvement associated with bacillary angiomatosis may cause fever, chills, malaise, night sweats, anorexia, and weight loss.

Diagnosis: Most often based on clinical features coupled with biopsies of lesions. Detection of Bartonella DNA in tissue specimens by polymerase chain reaction (PCR) assay or of Bartonella antigens by immunohistochemical methods is diagnostic. Warthin starry staining reveals large clusters of bacteria. 

Failure to distinguish Kaposi sarcoma from bacillary angiomatosis is problematic because bacillary angiomatosis, unlike Kaposi sarcoma, responds dramatically to antibiotic therapy. Furthermore, bacillary angiomatosis may be life-threatening if untreated. Treatment: Erythromycin or doxycycline for 3 months.

Option A: Kaposi sarcoma presents with multifocal erythematous patches and plaques over the limb in a patient with HIV along with the histopathological image showing sheets of whorled spindle cells. Kaposi sarcoma is a multifocal endothelial proliferation of low‐grade malignant potential. It is seen in high association with AIDS (acquired immunodeficiency syndrome) and human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8).

Option B: Chickenpox or varicella is caused by the varicella-zoster virus. Most infections occur before the age of 5 but can occur in older children and adults. The lesions develop in 3-5 crops and are polymorphic (present at different stages in each site). In 2–4 days, a dry crust forms leaving a shallow pink depression which, in the absence of secondary infection, heals without scarring. It is non-contagious after the lesions have crusted.

Option D: Cryptococcal skin involvement presents with papulonodular necrotizing skin lesions with central umbilication, like molluscum contagiosum, and is usually encountered in the context of neurological or pulmonary disease.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with raised violaceous purple plaques on his buccal mucosa. He gave a history of undergoing a transplantation surgery a few months back and a provisional diagnosis of transplant-associated Kaposi sarcoma was considered. Which of the following statement is false regarding the same?

choices.text: More commonly seen in solid-organ transplants
Caused by alpha group of viruses in Herpesviridae family

questions.solution:
The false statement about transplant-related Kaposi sarcoma is it is caused by alpha group of viruses in the Herpesviridae family. Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) belonging to Gamma herpesviruses and is very common in patients suffering from acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). KS is considered to be an AIDS-defining disease. 

Herpesviridae family is divided into 3 subfamilies:

  • Alpha herpesviruses (e.g. HSV 1 and 2, varicella-zoster virus)
  • Beta herpes viruses (e.g. CMV, HHV 6, HHV 7)
  • Gamma herpesviruses (e.g. HHV8, EBV)

Transplant-associated KS is more common after solid organ transplant patients receive immunosuppression as compared to marrow or stem-cell transplant patients. There is a 100-fold greater risk in immunocompromised patients and has an aggressive course involving lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera. Cutaneous lesions may be absent. Lesions decrease as immunosuppression is reduced and rapamycin can also be used for management.

The other forms of KS are:

  • Classic Kaposi sarcoma: This occurs in older men of Eastern European and Meditteranean descent and has the following three clinical stages:
    • Patches- red-purple macules on the distal lower extremities
    • Plaques- patches progress to large violaceous raised plaques. Lesions spread proximally.
    • Nodules- Lesions become nodular with more neoplastic features. This stage also progresses to involve nodes and viscera.
  • Endemic African KS: It is common in Central Africa. This occurs in HIV-seronegative individuals, usually aged below 40 years. Lymph node involvement is more common than in classic variant and is very aggressive in prepubertal children with 100% mortality in 3 years.
  • AIDS-associated KS: KS is an AIDS-defining illness and is the most common malignancy associated with HIV infection. AIDS-associated KS often involves lymph nodes and disseminates widely to the viscera early in its course; most patients eventually die of opportunistic infections rather than KS.

Related Pearl: Classification of Kaposi sarcoma

Classic

  • Older men of eastern European and Meditteranean origin
  • Not associated with HIV
  • Skin plaques and nodules

Endemic African

  • Seen in HIV seronegative individuals
  • Predominant lymph node and visceral involvement

Transplant associated

  • Solid organ transplant recipients
  • Involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera
  • Cutaneous lesions may be absent

AIDS-associated epidemic KS

  • HIV infected individuals
  • Involves lymph nodes

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix
